LEESER LIBRARY,
HEBREW
EDUCATION SOCIETY.
DEDICATION
OF THE
Synagogue Beth-El-Emeth.
From the Occident for October, 1857.

ANOTHER house devoted to the service of the God of Israel was dedi-
cated in our city on Thursday the 14th of Elul (the 3d of September),
and a new congregation was thus instituted to take its rank and respon-
sibility among the communities established to uphold the law which is
the heritage of Jacob's sons.

We announced in our last that it was intended to open the new Syna-
gogue, bearing the name of Beth-El-Emeth, and situated in Franklin
Street, Philadelphia, on the above day; and we are truly happy to state
that nothing interfered with the execution of the plan. About half past
four the people began to assemble; and the weather being beautiful,
allowed persons of all ages to venture forth to take part in the solemni-
ties of the occasion; and it was pleasing to see with what apparent cor-
diality the ministers and presidents of the other congregations, all being
represented except one, joined us that day. We noticed the Reverend
Isidor Frankel, and Messrs. Joseph Einstein and Jacob Mayer President
and Vice President of Rodef Sholem; Reverend Solomon Jacobs,
and Mr. Harris Coleman President of the Beth Israel; Reverend L.
Naumburg, and Mr. Adolph Klopfer President of the Kenesseth Israel;
and the Reverend S. C. Noot, and Mr. Henry De Boer President of the
Bnai Israel Synagogues, besides many members of the respective con-
gregations, including the Mikve Israel, the oldest in the city, as also a
large number of non-Israelites. Although it was hoped that the service
would commence at five P. M. precisely, some little delay took place
owing to the late arrival of many persons; but at about 20 minutes past
that hour an overture, solemn and appropriate, was commenced by the

band, led by Mr. A. Scherzer, an Israelite well known for his skill in
the tuneful art; and while this was being executed the Minister fol-
lowed by six members of the congregation, each bearing a Sepher To-
rah, approached the right entrance door of the main hall. When the
music ceased the customary knocks were given to ask admittance within
the precincts of the sanctuary, and the usual verse, "Open for me the gates
of righteousness," &c., was recited, when Rev. Mr. Frankel responded
"This is the gate of the Lord," &c., while the procession entered and
proceeded to the Tebah. The choir attached to the Rodef Sholem
Synagogue then sang Hebrew, "Blessed be he who cometh in the name
of the Lord," &c. This being completed, the grace Hebrew (Shehecheyanu)
was recited by the Hazan, while Mr. M. D. Cohen the Secretary of our
congregation lighted the Perpetual Lamp (Hebrew) as a descendant of
Aaron; and Mr. Joseph Einstein opened the doors of the Ark. Next
followed Hebrew "I will thank thee," &c., by the choir. A symphony was
then performed by the band, and the Bearers of the Law-books, having
changed according to the printed programme which had been generally
distributed, Psalm xxx. was sung by the choir, while the procession
moved round the Tebah for the first circuit. After another piece of
music, Psalm cxxvii. followed for the second circuit; after which Hebrew
"The Lord will reign," &c., and Psalm xxix. were chaunted by the con-
gregation, while the Sepharim were carried to and deposited in the Ark.
The Hazan then recited Hebrew, and this was followed by Hebrew by
the choir, then by music from the band; in the meanwhile the Hazan
had ascended the pulpit in front of the Hechal, and when the sound of
the instruments had ceased, he delivered the following address, which
is given, by request, in our pages:
THE HOUSE OF THE TRUE GOD.
BROTHERS OF THE HOUSE OF ISRAEL:

WE have assembled to-day for the first time in this house, to
dedicate it to the worship of the True God, to Him who created
the heavens and the earth and all which fills universal space;
and we accordingly devote it, during the time that we or other
Israelites have possession of this building, to the service of the
Most High, in order that His NAME may here be invoked by all
who may desire to associate with us in the adoration of the Being
whose providence cares for all, and whose omniscience surveys all
the secrets of the hearts of men.
We stand thus for the first time in the presence of our Maker

as a new association of His adorers, with our wives and little
ones, to declare that we also desire to be known as a special
society among other communities of Israel, as men devoted to
that cause which was handed down from the most ancient days
as an heir-loom of the descendants of Abraham; and that we are
ready to labor with a thorough good-will, with united hearts and
souls, for the maintenance of the blessed faith which has been our
life and preservation, even from the day that it was entrusted to
our safe-keeping when we were assembled at the foot of Horeb,
until this hour when we are congregated in this house which we
have called that of the TRUE GOD, of Him who was, who is, and
who will be. It is therefore a momentous occasion which has called
us together, and it well deserves to be pondered on, that it may
never depart from our memory, while the spirit within us is
united to the perishable frame, and the divine spark which con-
stitutes our life is connected with the mortal clay which is its
dwelling, and that the recollection may accompany us to the
moment when the angel of death comes to release the soul to
bear it away to its resting place at the foot of Mercy's throne.—
Let us take for our text Joshua xxii. 34:
Hebrew:

"And the children of Reuben and the children of Gad called the altar
("Ed"); for (they said) it is a witness between us that the Eternal One
is God."

This passage occurs in one of the last chapters of the book of
Joshua, and is the conclusion of the history of the altar which the
two and half tribes whose domain was on the east side of the Jordan
had erected on the bank of that river, when they returned to their
homes after having assisted the western tribes in conquering the
land of Canaan. It is well known to you, that no altar was per-
mitted to be erected in the whole country of Israel besides the
one which was near the tabernacle, and later, the temple on Mo-
riah. When, therefore, news was brought to the other Israelites
of this occurrence, they at once assembled at Shiloh to send out
an army against what they thought the rebellious tribes to coerce
them to obedience. But before proceeding to such extremes they
dispatched a deputation of eleven of the principal chiefs, among
whom was the zealous Phineas, prudent as he was daring, to

remonstrate with the men of Reuben and their confederates on
account of the great transgression of which they presumed them
guilty. These, however, answered deprecatingly and said: "The
God of gods, the Eternal One, the God of gods, the Eternal One,
he knoweth, and Israel also shall know: if it be in rebellion, or
if in transgression against the Lord, (aid us not this day,) that
we have built us an altar to turn away from following the Lord;
or if to offer thereon burnt offering or meat offering, or if to offer
thereon peace-offerings, may the Lord himself require it." In
the same strain they continued to asseverate their good intentions,
and finished by saying that it should be regarded as a perpetual
testimony between the portions of Israelites divided from each
other by the Jordan, that both the ones and the others believed
in the same God whom they all then adored. And when Phineas
and his companions had been gratified by this declaration of
faith, and had departed for their homes, the trans-Jordanic tribes
gave to the altar the name which designated it to be to them a
testimony, that in every possible contingency of life the Lord
should be alone their God, and that they would regard His altar
at the tabernacle as the only centre of worship; thus pledging
themselves to offer up their devotions solely after the manner
laid down in the divine law. It is well to understand distinctly
the condition of the world when the Reubenites and their imme-
diate confederates made this avowal;—the legislation of Sinai
was yet new, and they were only the second generation that had
become familiar with it; all around them, nay, in their own coun-
try and neighborhood, were many tribes that worshipped idols,
indulged in carnal practices interdicted by the Mosaic law, and in
brief, were as different in thought and action from the standard
of righteousness which they had themselves received, as it is pos-
sible to be. They were therefore exposed to many temptations
to fall of by degrees from the road of life they had traveled un-
der Moses and Joshua, and to become either like the Egyptians
in whose land they had been bondsmen, or like the Canaanites
among whom they then dwelt. It was no doubt this considera-
tion which impelled the assembled Israelites at Shiloh to endeavor
to crush what they supposed the incipient infection of pagan life
by a terrible blow, though a universal carnage of the rebels

might be the result. But the suspected tribes, on the contrary,
then declared that they did not desire to multiply places of sacri-
fice after the manner of the idolators, who fancied that frequent
acts of devotion, performed in many places, were requisite to
propitiate their gods; but that they would, after the simpler
fashion of the Scripture-commands, resort only to the spot
chosen by God out of all their tribes to offer up there and there
alone all that had been commanded, and just as it had been or-
dained; and that the very altar they had erected on the banks
of the Jordan, standing as it should, in solitude and silence, with-
out smoke to arise from its hearth, without a priest to keep watch
near it, without the festive crowd to encamp in its precincts on
the stated seasons of pilgrimage, should prove in the strongest
manner, that the structure was merely a testimony to all behold-
ers, that the stream which divides Palestine into two unequal
parts, did not separate the people into two sects; but that both
the inhabitants of the East and the West were bound together by
the ties of one faith, having one country, one origin, one religion,
one altar, and one God!

We, too, my friends, stand here this day before the world with
a new structure which we have dedicated to the cause of religion;
but it is not a new faith which is to be symbolised here, no new
worship which is to be introduced within these walls; and all
Israel, if all were witnesses here this day, should see, that
neither in rebellion, nor in transgression against the Most High,
nor in malevolence towards our brothers of other societies has
the work been begun and thus far completed; but to cement the
stronger our adherence to God's most holy law, and to fortify
ourselves in the attachment to the whole household of Israel,
which was once so strong and beautiful, but which has, alas! so
greatly waned in the troublous times through which we have had
to pass. You must not forget, my brothers, that, though we are
not surrounded by the idols of Egypt, nor by the abominations
of Canaan, our warfare with the world without is not accomplished.
Our faith has its enemies in the circumstance that we are still a
peculiar people, with laws which separate us from the board and
communion of non-Israelites; in the fact that we adore a NAME
who is not yet enthroned alone and solely in the hearts of man,

though He is alone and solely the TRUE GOD, the Creator of all
things. Political power and influence are, as such, no necessary
appendage to the household of Israel; but we are scattered,
strewn like the seed from the pouch of the ploughman, over the
surface of the earth, to be controlled and trammeled by all who
differ from us, and who unite in this, when even differing ever so
widely among themselves, that it is for the benefit of the world
at large, that the Hebrew race should be watched and kept with-
in the narrowest possible bounds, lest their creed should spread,
and their religion attain to that degree of power, that it might
work an injury unto those modes of thought and practice to
which the various sections of mankind are devoted. This hostil-
ity is at the same time not always a mere passive dislike, which
shows itself in an unwillingness to associate with us on terms of
equality, and to grant us that weight in the historical develop-
ment of the world which would of right be due to our industry,
probity, and intelligence, or in short, to treat us as one man
usually treats the other; but in many quarters of the globe active
measures of repression and coercion are resorted to, in order to
vex us with restraints and burdens which others are exempt from,
and to offer all possible inducements to those, whose heart is not
sincere, to forsake a faith which brings no worldly gain, and to
cast off the connection with a people which the laws of the land
and public prejudice stigmatize as inferior to the other classes of
the inhabitants. Though millions of martyrs have at all periods
of history testified by their death, under incredible tortures of
body and mind, that no suffering was capable to withdraw them
from their God and his law: still experience has proved that many
have yielded to the allurement of public offices to either become
apostates altogether, or to shape their conduct so that their Juda-
ism was rendered undistinguishable to the unpractised eye, so
that such as these at times boast of having so well disguised their
inherited religion, as not to be suspected of belonging to its ad-
herents. Others again there are who daily make the amount of
duties to be performed less and less, because they fancy themselves
exempt from its behests in this enlightened age of the world, and
so approximate the Gentile freedom from the precepts, that they
gradually lapse into infidelity, or they unconsciously almost join

one of the sects around them, and this perhaps, not immediately
in their own persons, but in those of their offspring, who, never
having been initiated into the practice of the duties, and never
having been imbued with the full force and beauty of the doc-
trines which lie as the basis of our lives, have no safeguard to
ward off temptation, nor any tangible reasons for remaining nom-
inally Jews when all the substance has long since been evaporated
into air in the life of their progenitors, by a constantly more
accelerated process of spiritualizing those distinctive acts which,
by the scriptural enactments, ought to distinguish the conduct of
every son of Israel. This latter species of apostacy is more com-
mon where we enjoy a moderate or entire share of equality of
civil and political rights, than where we are oppressed and ex-
cluded from participating in the privileges of citizenship. The
very distance of the danger will bring us within its grasp. Tell
a man, when he begins to acquire wealth and distinction, that he
has taken the first step to banish his sons from the precincts of
the Synagogue, and he will exhibit all the appearances of offended
rectitude. For he will tell you, that he is engaged in a pursuit
which will exhibit him to the world as an ornament to human
nature; that he trusts, with the help of Heaven, to prove what the
Jew is capable of achieving if his genius is unchecked; and that
he will nevertheless take heed that all in his household shall
know that they are Israelites, the possessors of a faith of which
they should justly be proud. But if we look on him again at a
later period, we may find that he has by degrees relaxed the
strict discipline which once prevailed in his home; that he has
so many engagements, that he is not able to watch all the walks
in which his children tread the course of life; that while he toils
for large gains, or fame and position, they seek each their own
pleasures; become more and more strangers to the house of God;
lapse by degrees into non-Jewish society; form intimacies which
deaden the last spark of devotion in their souls; and that they
succeed, perchance, to withdraw their aged and now helpless
parents from the close communion with their brothers, ashamed
and degraded in their own estimation, or entrapped into actual
transgression, by the misconduct of those who, they once vainly
hoped, would perpetuate their name as a house honored among

the descendants of Jacob. By this process of self-exaltation,
and a gradually increasing contempt for the association with
other Israelites, which led the children to cast off the little re-
straint the parental teaching had at first imposed on them, families
once numerous among us are approaching their extinction, and
it is possible that in a few generations not one of them will be
left to swear fealty to the Eternal God. Yet the transition was
very slow at first; in the beginning it was perhaps a substitution
of the first for the seventh day of the week as the Sabbath of the
Lord; next visiting places of instruction where a faith different
from ours was taught; then a gradual withdrawal from those who
were professing Jews, because they stood not as high in the world's
estimation; then the covenant of Abraham was neglected; or
the daughter of the son of the stranger entered into family rela-
tions with the child of Jacob; and thus the way was left open
for a quiet mingling as a member with one of the non-Jewish
associations; and in this way a name and a family have perished
in Israel.

But not alone those in an exalted position are thus lost to us;
many in inferior positions imitate the evil example set them by
the others; and they mingle with the debauchee and the outcast,
there to indulge their wicked inclinations, forsaking thereby the
home where humble piety dwells, and departing from the path of
the law, to their entire ruin. It is not necessary to produce illustra-
tions from our experience to prove the truth of what I have just
uttered; for all of you may, if they will tax their memory, verify
my words by what has fallen under their own observation; and
they will therefore acknowledge that we are not exempt from
danger, in the present posture of events, though we live not in
the midst of idolators, as did the Reubenites when they built the
altar near the Jordan. Let us, therefore, avail ourselves of this
occasion to reflect on the work before us. We enter this day into
a covenant with God, tacitly, if not in words, to be faithful to
Him, and to preserve the law "which is an inheritance of the
congregation of Jacob" for those who are to come after us. We
bind ourselves, by devoting this house especially to the attribute
of "Truth," which is the seal of the Creator under which He call-
ed the world into being, that we will guard the faith with all our

strength against the encroachment of error from whatever side
this might threaten it, and to show ourselves truthful in single-
ness of devotion to the precepts we have received. We shall be
indeed approached with appeals as to the unreasonableness of
an adherence to antiquated notions and practices; but this is the
very purpose which ought to engage us; and to succeed we ought
to search into what has come down from the days of antiquity.
Our very name is as ancient as history. Abraham was surnamed
the Hebrew, and this designation yet denotes his descendants;
Jacob was blest and called Israel, and we are therefore the proper
Israelites of whose future so much is said in the Holy Scriptures,
and of whom so many hopeful anticipations are entertained. It
would be now insulting to sound human reason to pause here to
prove that it would be impossible to preserve the identity of the
Israelites without the bond of the law; as without this, they
would soon cease to be distinguishable among the rest of man-
kind, and would thus disappear as agents from the work of history.
But to check the deterioration which was just alluded to, and to
preserve the identity of our race, which many have lost already,
we ought to resort to those measures which were found so effica-
cious in the days of Hezekiah and Josiah, kings of Judah, and
of Ezra and Nehemiah, when the Babylonian captivity had been
terminated by the re-building of the temple of Jerusalem. These
means were, first, a greater cordiality among the people, a more
intimate union for the purpose of furthering the observance of
the precepts of the Scriptures, and, secondly, an earnest endea-
vor to render all more familiar with the contents of the Scriptures
than they had been before. At a future day we shall no doubt
recur to this topic at greater length; our present purpose is
merely to sketch an outline of what is needed. When we were
still under one government, and had a country which we could
call our own, the heads of the state, such as judges, kings, princes,
governors, and high-priests, could, by their political power and
influence, contribute largely to the direct improvement of religion
and morals; hence we find that, in proportion as our rulers were
virtuous and pious, the people were so likewise. But at present,
other influences must be brought to bear on us, and they are,
simply, association and individual exertions. As regards the

first, let us observe that no matter how great a mind may dwell
in any man, he cannot labor except in a very limited sphere; he
can be only in one place at a time, and he is therefore liable to
be counteracted and defeated by the next comer, not so much by
the superior power of the other, as by his own absence, through
which means his influence is overcome by, perhaps, the mere as-
surance and impudent, bold, assertions of the other. It is for
this reason nothing new, that public bodies exhibit the incon-
stancy of the sea, as they are swayed often, not by a positive
rule of right, but by the opinion of the latest teacher. To avoid
this uncertainty and constant fluctuation, it is necessary to asso-
ciate together on a basis of unvarying principles, and to establish
a rule which nothing shall be able to overthrow. You have at-
tempted to carry this into practice, my friends, in the constitution
you have adopted, by laying down the irrevocable rule that you
will, as a body, have only those prayers which the great lights of
Israel delighted to employ in their addressing Him "who sitteth on
the throne of mercy;" and in so doing, you also declare that you
will faithfully and truly abide by the principles which the words
of these prayers inculcate. You have farther declared that only
Israelites in practice shall have a controlling power in your as-
semblies; the doors of this house shall indeed stand open wide,
to admit every one, the righteous one and the sinner, the son of
Abraham and him whose parentage is not of Israel, to offer up
here their devotion, and to pour out their heart before the Lord
in joy or in sorrow; since God himself has taught us that his
house should be a house of prayer to all people. At the same
time it has been resolved on wisely, to exclude all from the con-
trol of affairs whose own conduct would stamp them as unfit to
be trusted with a voice in the religious concerns of Israel. Hav-
ing thus commenced, let us hope that you will feel the weight of
the obligation resting on you, and that you will resolve to leave
nothing untried to induce each other to be strict in the observance
of all those duties in which so many are deficient, especially
the keeping of the Lord's Sabbath, that this house may not be
empty, while those, who have an interest here, seek their worldly
gains in their places of business; we will trust that you will stimu-
late each other to give all the children a knowledge of their faith

and of the language of Israel, that, when they come hither, the
words of the prayers may be familiar to their ears, and not sound to
them like an unmeaning jargon which makes nothing but an un-
pleasant impression on the mind. But individual exertions must not
be omitted, nor should any one wait to move in the expectation that
the public will and ought to go first forward. Whatever strikes
either of you as useful and practicable, he ought to bring before
the community and request in a courteous manner their co-opera-
tion; and in case it does not meet with as prompt support as
he has perhaps a right to expect, he should endeavor to see what
he can do alone, and labor to awake public attention to his plan,
and in the meanwhile accomplish all that an individual, single-
handed, is able to attain. Persuasion, honesty of purpose, and
unflagging industry, are almost unfailing means in insuring suc-
cess; and the empire of religion also needs servants animated
with these qualities to achieve a triumph over the enemies that
oppose its progress.

This is our object and purpose, union for the sake of our an-
cient faith, and for this each individual, let us hope, will labor
with all his soul; and as far as the efforts of him, whom you
have chosen as the messenger of your congregation, can avail, he
pledges himself, that whatever gifts of mind the Most Gracious
One has endowed him with, shall be devoted to the same end, so
that through us the name of God may be glorified in some little
measure. Much, feeble man cannot promise; he can accomplish
but little; it is only in the hands of the Almighty to bestow
success on all enterprises. This, however, we can safely declare,
that it is not in rebellion against the Lord, or to turn away from
Him that we have established this house of prayer, nor from
motives of malevolence against our brothers that we meet here
to perform our devotions: towards the Lord we declare, that we
will abide by the faith as our fathers delivered it to us; and to
our brothers we hold out the hand of fellowship, and we pledge
ourselves that we will, if in our power, act with all of them in
unison to forward all measures tending to the public welfare;
and while we invoke the blessing of God on our enterprise, we
also crave the good-will of all Israelites towards ourselves and
this house in which we shall hereafter assemble. And we farther

declare, that this house, and any other which may in future be
built, in case it should happen that the space here be not large
enough to receive all the worshippers that may resort hither to
unite with us in the adoration of the Most High, shall be forever
a witness against us in the judgment of God, that we mean now
and for all time, as a congregation of Israelites, to believe firmly
and faithfully in the sole existence of the Eternal God, who alone
created the heavens and formed the earth, whose spirit gives
knowledge, whose mercy saves, and whose power delivers; yes,
that we will be servants in life and unto death, of the Omnipotent
One who delivered our fathers from Egypt, and who will gather
their descendants unto his holy mountain under the guidance of
his anointed, the son of David. Amen.
PRAYER.

O Father and King! God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, look
down from thy high and holy dwelling on the children of the
dust, who have essayed to devote to Thee another house, where
thy name may abide among the descendants of thy servants. We
know our weakness, and that we are dust,—here this day in health
and prosperity, soon to be laid in the grave to moulder away as
our fathers before us. Only Thou livest to eternity, and to Thy
days there is no ending. We therefore turn to Thee, to crave
Thy presence with us in our coming on, that much spiritual bless-
ing may flow unto us from the meetings within these walls, so
that the taught and the teachers may issue thence invigorated by
Thy consolation, and instructed in the knowledge of Thy ways.
Let us also be strengthened by Thy inspiration, that the words
of Thy law may be pleasant to us, so that they may fructify
within us, and render us obedient to thy behests, and willing to
follow Thee, O Father! whether we live in prosperity, or perish
in earthly misery. Let Thy wisdom animate us, that we may be
shown how to distinguish between the true and the false, between
the apparent good and the real evil; that we may walk safely
before Thee and not be ensnared by the power of sin.

Let the spirit of counsel and understanding rest on the mana-
gers of this congregation and its members, that they may resolve
only on what will tend to promote Thy kingdom and spread good

will and friendship among all Thy servants who dwell in this city.
And wherever Thy children dwell let them be made conscious
that they are Thine, whom Thou didst purchase as Thy servants,
when Thou didst redeem them from Egyptian slavery, that they
might proclaim Thy glory and spread Thy name unto all the cor-
ners of the earth.—On the rulers and people of this city and
country also show Thy grace, that peace may dwell here, and the
clashing of armour not be heard, and plenty and contentment
reign everywhere around us; so that we of Thy household,
whose lot is here cast, may not be disturbed by the sound of bat-
tles, nor the pinching of famine, nor by political violence or op-
pression, and thus prevented from pursuing the course marked
out to us in Thy law, which is the life and permanence of Israel.
Yea, be with us all in our comings in and goings out, and let us
feel Thy presence wherever we may be assembled; and give us
the strength and proclaim Thy glory and to propagate Thy faith;
and let us be made conscious that Thou art indeed our God, even
the Creator of the world, the God of Truth, to all eternity.
Amen.

When the address was ended, the choir chaunted Psalm cl., after
which another piece of music was performed, during which time a vol-
untary collection was taken up, the amount of which we have not learned.
The Evening-service, the first ever recited in the new house, was then
read by the Hazan, and at its conclusion Yigdal was sung by the choir
led by Mr. Frankel, and a finale having then been played by the band,
the assemblage dispersed, apparently much gratified by what they had
witnessed. Much credit is due to Mr. Frankel and his able leader, Mr.
Jost, as also to the members of the choir for the generally excellent
manner in which the seven pieces performed by them were given, espe-
cially if one remembers that the brief notice which they had, permitted
them to sing at the new Synagogue for practice but once, and this on
the evening before the dedication. Mr. Scherzer and his musicians also
acquitted themselves well, and all deserve the thanks of the community
for the manner they aided to add to the solemnity of the occaison.

Our readers may, perhaps, expect of us a more detailed description;
but we were too much interested ourself to note any more than what
fell under our own immediate observation. We saw but few persons
distinctly, though, had we felt equal to the task of looking around, we
should have recognised, among some unknown, many familiar faces who

were observed at our ministration in former years. The attendance
was all that could be expected; though the crowd would undoubtedly
have been much greater, had it not been the busy season of the year,
and the hour chosen one in which the merchants were not able to leave
their stores. As it was, the order and general decorum observed, and
the undivided attention of the audience, were highly gratifying to all
concerned, and were, we trust, an earnest that the same will prevail to
a yet greater extent in the future meetings in the new house of prayer.

As it had been found impossible to procure Sepharim from Europe or
in this country since organizing the Kahal, we were indebted to the Ro-
def Sholem and Beth Israel congregations for the loan of five for the
above occasion, and we record their kindness with sincere gratification,
and trust that it will be in the power of our community to reciprocate,
with many acts of good-will, the evidence of brotherly love thus given.

On the eve of Sabbath, our first regular meeting for worship took
place, and the following morning a large assemblage of both sexes pre-
sented themselves to unite in prayer. The decorous attention paid to
the Synagogue on an equal footing with the best churches of other per-
suasions. Let us trust that this may be always so.—The offerings made
during the day were liberal, and, in short, people testified in every sense
of the word their gratification at the thus far successful issue of their
pious work, as it is the conviction of all that the establishment of this
institution was necessary, notwithstanding the existence of so many
other Synagogues in this city. There is room for all, and more space
will be required hereafter should the Israelites here increase in future
in the proportion they have done of late years. We say this merely to
quiet the fear of some, that an injury will result to others by our
movement.—After 'Alenu the Reverend Solomon Jacobs, who had been
specially invited, ascended the pulpit and delivered the following prayer
and address; and as they gave so much satisfaction to his hearers we
spread them before our readers, that they too may be edified thereby.

We would only state, that Mr. J. spoke without any notes, and he
has written down what follows merely from memory; wherefore he can-
not be held responsible for the accuracy of every word as here given, but
for the general correctness of the ideas enforced before the audience;
and this is all that can be expected in any report of a lecture, that it be
a true transcript of the views advanced and defended, the words used
being merely the outward dress of the productions of the mind.
THE OBJECT OF THE SYNAGOGUE.
BY THE REV. SOLOMON JACOBS.
PRAYER.

FROM thy glorious abode, Oh! Almighty Father, look down
upon us, and receive the prayer which we, thy children, bring this
day to the throne of thy Omnipotence!

From this sacred pile which we have dedicated to thy pure
and holy name, we offer Thee an incense, not of the odors of
flowers culled from verdant hill and smiling vale,—not of the bal-
sams of Gilead, not the myrrh and musk of Africa's fragrant
fields,—not an incense distilled from the Elysian groves of Ara-
bia, elaborated by the skilful hands of eastern balmists, such as
the descendants of Aaron, thy anointed servants, brought Thee
in the sanctuary raised on the hills of Zion; but an incense pure
and holy, an incense whose latent virtues we have extracted out
of the elements of virtue, sincerity, and a meek and contrite
spirit. This is the incense which we bring to Thee on this, the first
Sabbath on which we assemble in this house, raised to thy honor
and glory. We have no other! Wilt Thou not accept this trib-
ute of our sincere affection? Yea, verily Thou wilt! For Thou,
Oh Lord! desirest not the offering of rams, and the odors of
flowers, but the sacrifice of a sincere and broken spirit. Oh!
that the offering which we bring Thee this day, may rise up
unto Thee. Oh! that it may ascend and purify the nauseous
atmosphere caused by the exhalations of unholy thoughts and
impure hearts. Oh! Almighty Father, it was by thy kindness,
grace, and love, that strengthened by the bonds of attachment,
those engaged in the holy task, were enabled to rear this house,
to thy solemn and sacred worship. From these walls, therefore,
which stand now as monuments of truth to testify to thy unity,
thy glory, and thy majesty, we bring here an offering which we
have culled in the silent hour of the night, when we have stood
transfixed in mute wonder and astonishment gazing on thy pro-
found goodness and immaculate wisdom, as manifested in the super-
nal work of heaven,—yea, an offering whose saving power we have

derived out of the universal garden of thy munificence, when we
have reflected day after day upon thy wondrous works, and been
refreshed by the sweet and softening influence of thy Divine
grace and mercy which fell down upon us like dew-drops at even
tide. We bring Thee an offering of faith—the faith which has
stood so long and will forever endure, the faith of our ancestors,
who bled and died in behalf of thy truth. Yea, we bring Thee
the offering of a faith, pure and unadulterated, the faith in thy
own entity; for as Thou, Oh God! art one an indivisible, so is
the faith on which we stand, as on a firm and indissoluble rock.
And on this eternal foundation of Israel's hope, and Israel's
trust, we gather our wives, and sons, and daughters, our aged,
and our young, and with hands bearing the censer of a holy and
spotless incense, with lips sanctified by the hallowing words of
inspiration, and with hearts heated by the fires of an intense and
devoted love, and our spirits melted and fused into one element
of devotion, sincerity, and earnest affection, we stand this day in
thy presence, and entreat Thee to bless this house and those who
have assembled therein. Make this sanctuary a place of refuge to
those who seek relief from the cares and sorrows of an oppress-
ing world. Oh! that it may prove a fountain of health to the
sick when they come here to beseech thy healing hand. Oh!
that it may afford enlargement to those who have been pressed
by misfortune and trouble. Oh! that it may be the means of
directing the sinner to seek forgiveness for his trespasses; and
grant that it may tend to cement the hearts of thy people, severed
by contention and strife, and bring about peace, harmony, union, and love. Amen.

BELOVED Brethren and ye Daughters of the House of Israel!
let me direct your serious attention to the fifteenth verse of the
twenty-sixth chapter of Deuteronomy, which is to be found in
that portion of HOLY WRIT which was read this morning.
Hebrew:

"Look down from the habitation of thy holiness from the heavens, and
bless thy people Israel, and the soil which thou hast given unto us, as thou
hast sworn unto our fathers, a land flowing with milk and honey."
On a day like this, which is the initiatory Sabbath, to what I

hope and trust may prove a long succession of days, Sabbaths,
and festivals, on which many worshippers of the true God, of
Israel may come into this house and pour out their souls' de-
votion to the Lord of hosts,—on a Sabbath like this, the first on
which we have met in this new house dedicated to Israel's God,
out of love and honor for His great and exalted name, and in
adoration of His Divine Majesty, it is befitting that we should turn
an earnest and longing eye to the land of our glorious nationality,
the land of our fathers, the progenitors of that wonderfully pre-
served race of men, known as the children of Israel. Yea, it is
befitting that we should turn our eyes and our hearts to the land
of our origin, the land where Judaism was cradled, nursed,
and fondly caressed by our devoted fathers and mothers. Yea,
it is befitting that we should look to that land where stood the
one sole Temple, erected on Mount Moriah, dedicated to the
worship of the one true God of Israel. Yes, my friends, it is
particularly our duty on a day like this, to pray with a fervent
and pious heart in the words of our text, using the very terms
directed to be used by our law-giver Moses when our ancestors
made their offering in the sanctuary of the produce of the field
blessed with an abundant harvest. "Look down from the habita-
tion of thy holiness from the heavens, and bless thy people Israel,
and the soil which Thou has given unto us, as Thou hast sworn
unto our fathers, a land flowing with milk and honey." Blessed
as we have been in this glorious land of freedom, with all the
rights and privileges of citizens, enjoying the right each to pursue
his avocation, and to go on unmolested in the path which he has
struck out for himself, whereby he may gain the summit of his fair
and honest wishes; favored as we have been here with the means
to procure wealth as a reward for our industry, and to enjoy those
rational and legitimate pleasures which wealth enables us to obtain,
as well as it does the followers of any other faith; open as the soil
here is to the honest plough, worked by Jewish hands as well as by
those of the worthy Gentile; unrestricted as is every channel of
trade, commerce, manufactures, and the arts, and open as is every
avenue to the different professions which grace this land of liberty;
yea, permitted as we have been by the varied blessings which we
here enjoy to erect this place of worship, not only as a place of

prayer to seek God's mercy to relieve us from oppression, but as
a place of thanksgiving to God for His manifold bounties: it is
befitting that we should turn to Jerusalem a wistful eye, lest in
the exuberance of our joyous emotions we might forget our ori-
gin, our nationality, and in the pride of vanity, and the folly of
forgetfulness, think this to be the consummation of all our hopes
and aspirations, and that Israel's destiny has been fulfilled in
the right which some portion of its fold has to erect unmolested
in this land aplace to the honor and glory of God, and to enjoy
all the blessings of life equally with other members of this great
confederated band of men basking in the sunshine of a glorious
Republic. Let us not imagine, my friends, that our whole duty
has been accomplished in erecting this sacred house of worship.
We have not erected this house solely because we live here and
enjoy here the manifold blessings of liberty, or because we have
been permitted here to enjoy the reward of our honest labor.
No, while we have erected this house as we are in duty bound to
erect houses of prayer and thanksgiving wherever the dispersed
of Israel may be scattered and located, as a mark of our devo-
tion to God: we should bear in mind that glorious temple, the
dwelling place of the Shechina which dwelt in the midst of Israel
in the land of promise, a land flowing with milk and honey. Here
let us pray, that the blessing of God may again descend upon
the patrimony of Israel. Here let us pray, that God may again
visit the land which He gave unto us as He swore unto our
fathers. Here let us pray, that He may send his anointed to
re-unite all the dispersed of Israel under one banner, and lead us
all back again to the soil which He swore to give unto us as our
everlasting inheritance. Here let us reflect on our origin, let us
remember that we are indeed the sons of a glorious ancestry who
suffered, bled, and died for the truth as it was given to us from
Sinai, and practised and sustained by the pious and faithful in
the land of Judea. It is essential, my friends, to the preservation
of our faith, and the sacred ordinances of our Divine law, that
we should turn our eyes to the city of Zion, as we shall endeavor
to make it apparent in the course of our remarks. Whatever
then, my friends, may be the solemn purpose for which we have
erected this Synagogue, we owe it in the first place to our ori-

gin, to our faith, to the memory of our glorious ancestors, to
remember Zion, and to pray to the Almighty that He may look
down from His glorious abode from heaven and bless his people
Israel, and the soil which He has given unto us, as He swore unto
our ancestors, "a land flowing with milk and honey."

But, my friends, that we may more readily know and under-
stand our duties in this Synagogue, let us inquire into four
things. First: Why have we built this Synagogue? Second:
What are the principles which should govern us in this Syna-
gogue? Third: What should the Synagogue be to us? And
Fourth and lastly: What should we be to the Synagogue?

And, first: Why have we built this Synagogue? My friends,
in proposing the first question, I wish you distinctly to under-
stand that I can have nothing at all to do with any of the political
reasons which contributed towards the erection of this edifice
into a Jewish house of worship. Whatever may have been the
ordinary or extraordinary causes by which this consummation was
effected, can have nothing, and has nothing to do with my consi-
deration of the question under discussion. It is enough for me
to know that whenever a place of worship is established by the
children of Israel, a bright and luminous star is added to the
already shining and illustrious constellation of the Jewish race;
another appendage to the pure and spotless banner of the house
of Jacob. It is enough for me to know that whenever and wher-
ever a Synagogue is erected, we have established another monu-
ment to the living and sacred truth of our holy faith and heaven-
born religion.

Yes, my brethren, I find an answer readily suggested to the
inquiry, in the fact that Hebrew when
Synagogues are spread over the land from where the sun rises
in the morning to the place where he sets in the evening, the
name of the Lord shall thereby be extolled. This is the reason
why this Synagogue has been established. There runs, my friends,
a holy current of feeling in the Jewish heart, which throbs,
expands, dilates, and seeks expression in an outward form.
There reigns a holy conviction in the Jewish mind, that God the
Creator is the Sovereign who alone should be adored;—and it is
this thought, this conviction, which clothes itself in an outward

garb, denominated public worship. It is this intensely felt sen-
sation which awakens in us the desire to multiply places of wor-
ship, wherein we can give expression to our most holy feelings.
If the Jew were really callous and indifferent about his faith, he
would not trouble himself about places of worship, he would not
incur the expense of multiplying houses of prayer. He might
say, "Whenever I feel disposed to pray, I can find some place of
worship where I can attend." But no, whatever may be his mo-
tives for not attending other places of worship already in exist-
ence, he cannot sit down in a state of indifference: he must be up
and doing, he must exemplify his love for his faith by the erection
of a place of worship where he can attend without any scruples.

Would you, my brethren, then know the reason why this place
of worship has been added to the many already in existence?
Then I answer, it is because proofs are being every day added of
the truth of the faith of Israel; because proofs are being every day
added that the spirit, the essence, the principles of the Jewish
religion hold a predominating sway, exercise a profoundly felt
influence in the Jewish breast.

But again, let me ask, Why have we instituted this place of
worship? My friends, we have done so at the express command
of God. It is the bounden duty of Israelites to erect a house of
worship, in other words, a house for God to dwell therein. As
soon as the Israelite feels the conviction that he is under the
providential care and government of One sole and indivisible
God, then it is his duty to unite with his brethren in rendering
homage to that Being in a house dedicated to His worship. God
has commanded our fathers, Hebrew, "Make me
a sanctuary, and I will dwell amongst them." We need not be
told by the philosopher, that a Being whose essence is incom-
prehensible, whose nature is beyond human ken, whose Divine
character is a profound mystery to us, who is omnipotent, omni-
scient, and omnipresent, cannot be circumscribed and confined
within the narrow limits of four walls. We need not be told by
the man of reason, that the creature cannot make a place for the
Creator; for the Scriptures themselves speak of the boundless
majesty of God,—and we require no better exponent of this idea
than the words of our text, in which we are directed to pray that

God, in His infinite goodness, may look down from heaven His
abode. Yea, my friends, heaven is His abode, the whole unlimit-
ed space of infinite worlds, the whole universal structure of
heaven and earth, and the illimitable regions of an infinite ex-
tension, which even the mind, in its ascending flights of bold ima-
gination, cannot reach—all this is filled with His glory. Full well
we know then, that this house cannot contain the majesty of God.
Why then have we built this house? We have done so, my friends,
that through this act of devotion the spirit of God may dwell in us.
A bright luminary in Israel, the author of Akedath Yizchak,
(Hebrew) says, that our religion may be compared to a stupen-
dous building. In looking at it, we first gaze upon its materials,
next upon its order, next to its stability, and lastly its purpose.
In looking, my friends, at a Synagogue, both ideas, the ideas
connected with the characteristics of a building, and the charac-
teristics of our religion, are intimately associated. What is the
purpose of this building? The answer is self-evident, Religion!
What else, pride, or vanity, or ambition? No! no! religion,
the desire to accelerate the means of our approach to God, and
to bring the influence of His Divine spirit to reside in our midst;
this is the solemn purpose for which we have erected this house
of prayer. We can, in fact, my friends, form no better idea of
the purposes of the Synagogue, than in reflecting upon the say-
ing of some of the sages of Israel. Wherefore was the temple
built in Jerusalem? Because, they say, it was erected in a direct
line with the sanctum sanctorum of heaven. Palestine, my friends,
is situated in the centre of the world. As God, therefore, who is
the real sanctuary and the concentration of holiness, is the centre
of all His great works, which derive life and consistency from Him
alone, and which would, without His sustaining breath, fall into
atoms and become consumed by the withering blast of His
anger: so is religion, which is symbolized by the earthly sanc-
tuary, the centre of the moral world. Without religion there
would be no morality. Without places of worship dedicated to
the God of Israel, there would be no true religion. The Syna-
gogue is the centre of true religion,—there men unite to adore
the true God, the Creator of heaven and earth,—there men de-
sire that life and sustaining breath which keep together the

moral and social fabric of the world,—there men learn those vital
principles and duties of love and friendship, which are the pillars
upon which the temple of harmony is firmly built. The Syna-
gogue should be built in a direct line with the sanctuary of Hea-
ven; so that the stream of God's love might flow from the peren-
nial spring of His Divine solicitude upon us, and refresh, invigo-
rate, and sustain our hearts. This, my friends, is the reason why
we have built this Synagogue. Oh! that it may always be the
centre around which our holiest emotions might cling. Oh! that
it may always stand in a direct line with the sanctuary of Heaven,
that the dews of love, mercy, and grace may descend and refresh
our hearts.

Secondly: What are the principles which should govern us in
the Synagogue? The difficulties which I might have encountered
in addressing any other audience but a Jewish one, and on any
other subject but the present, I do not experience. Thank God!
I am addressing my own brethren, one with me in the spirit and
in the flesh,—indoctrinated in the same eternal principles of faith,
—and united by the same ties, having the same attachments,
the same fond hopes and aspirations, in whose hearts burn the
same intense flame of Sinaic fire, who live in the same reverence
for the undying word of God: yea, I address the sons of Jacob
initiated into the covenant of Abraham,—the daughters of the holy mothers
of Israel who valued the word of inspiration more than they did
life, who knew how to spurn every attempt to draw them from
their faith, their plighted troth, who could frown upon princes
and despise palaces, who could find contentment and happiness
in the lot and condition of outcast Israel, who loved their God
in solitude, and hated affluence when it conflicted with their con-
scientous convictions of duty. Such sons and such daughters
am I, thank God, this day permitted to address; and speaking in
the name of such a religion and to such a people, I can have no
difficulty in defining the principles which should govern us in,
yea, and out of the Synagogue.

What other principles than those long established ancient, ay,
and permanent principles of truth which have ever governed the

chosen people of God, should influence us in the Synagoge? what
other than those long cherished doctrines of the Jewish creed, in
maintaining which our forefathers died, and suffered every species
of cruelty and unheard of tortures, should rally us round our
banner? what other than those principles of a vital and soul-sav-
ing conviction in the truth of our Divine legacy, bequeathed to
us by our fathers, which they derived from the pure and living
fount of Sinai, should incite us to renewed vigor and zeal in our
attachment to the house which we have dedicated to God?

Remember, my friends, the name by which we have designated
this temple, and it will best inform you of the principles which
should ever guide you in your pious and holy labor. The name
of this house is at once expressive of your duties and the princi-
ples which are to govern you here and elsewhere. This place
has been very happily denominated Beth-El-Emeth, Hebrew,
"The house of the true God." We come here to worship truth.
We come here to adore a Being who is the embodiment of truth.
We come here to give expression to the convictions of our mind,
and to pour out the sincere feelings of our hearts. Truth and
sincerity are the characteristics of the homage which we meet
here to pay to our God—God is truth, therefore must the
principles which regulate us here be founded and exercised in
truth. Yes, my friends, the name of this house will best indicate
the principles which should govern us therein.

We may strive to be ever so moral, ever so chaste, ever so
pure, ever so honest, ever so charitable, and ever so humane;
our daughters may be trained in all the elegancies of refinement,
their tastes for the graceful, the beautiful, the delicate, the soft,
the pathetic, and the tender may be ever so much improved; our
sons may be reared in all the paths of an improved, bold, coura-
geous, and independent manhood; they may be taught the no-
ble lessons of industry, frugality, sobriety, and the other virtues,
—we may strive by all the appliances of natural instruction to
make them perfectly moral; but, my friends, unless this educa-
tion, unless the effort to improve our moral condition be founded
on the fundamental basis of the Divine truth revealed to us by
the Eternal, our improvement will be but an idle bauble. Virtue

depending solely upon what is termed the moral sense of right
and wrong, is at best a weak and unreliable staff, a reed which is
easily broken,—it is not that column of strength, capable of sup-
porting the upper building in the stormy season, when the ele-
ments are lashed in fury. That virtue, which is not founded in
the conviction of the truth of revelation, which teaches us our
duties, and demands of us obedience to the moral law in virtue of
the holy character of a God who delights in the virtue of His
servants, and who will punish those who do not conform to His
immaculate will,—that virtue, I say, is not calculated to stand the
trials of temptation. It is a conviction of the truth alone which
renders the heart impervious to the shafts of sin, and the seduc-
tive influences of certain crimes clad in the habiliments of a
graceful ease and worldly indifference. The solemn assurance,
the well-grounded belief in the certainty and truth of our holy
religion are the best safeguards which we can set round our sons
and our daughters as bulwarks to ward off the attacks of the
enemy, transgression.

And however abundant the lip-worship, however expensive the
sacrifice, however costly the mansion, however great the show
and parade which we make in our public assemblies for the pur-
pose of prayer,—if they are not derived from the one great prin-
ciple of truth,—if these are not rendered out of obedience to the
law of Sinai,—if all this is not done in conformity with an earnest
and soul-felt impression that our religion, however good and use-
ful, is not the product of man's reason, but the certain and
positive expression of the Divine and Eternal word of God: our
words, our labor, our expense, our trouble, our thoughts, our
feelings, and all our doings will only prove abhorrent in the sight
of God. Our charitable feelings will not endure, our benevolence
will soon turn into inclemency, and all the virtues upon which
we may for the present pride ourselves will not cling to us. We
shall soon suggest expedients, motives, and apparently staunch
and proper reasons for treating our fellow-man with coldness and
indifference; but not so when truth is our guiding star; not so
when truth is raised on a high and prominent pole; not so when
the spirit of a firm conviction in the truths of our religion is re-
flected from all the high places of Israel. For then shall we at

all times walk in its ways. Truth will teach us to look upon dis-
tress with a pitying eye, and extend thereto a commiserating hand.
Truth will teach us to know that we are the work of a good, and
just, and merciful, and upright God, who is omniscient and sees
us all, and knows our thoughts and actions, and who will bring
all His works into judgment.

This view is forcibly expressed, my brethren, in one of the alle-
gories of the Jewish sages—where one of our Rabbins says: Hebrew:
"When the Deity was about to create man, the angels formed
themselves into companies. One said, Create him, the other said,
Create him not. Kindness said, Create him, seeing that he will
perform acts of beneficence; but Truth said, Create him not, for
he will be filled with lies. Charity said, Create him, for he will
perform offices of charity; but Peace said, Create him not, for he
will be full of strife; but the Eternal threw truth down upon
the earth, as it is written in Daniel: 'And he cast truth down
upon the earth.'" In these few words, my friends, our sages de-
velop the whole theory of our moral and religious being. They
show us the antithesis of our nature. Man could not exist by
the means of a moral principle alone; for, while his nature might
at times prompt him to acts of benevolence, it would at others
falsify his professions of virtue; while he might at times be in-
clined to charity, strife, which is an inherent element of our
nature, would obtain an overwhelming influence over him, and
destroy the peaceful agency of love and charity. But truth, the
truth of religion, the truth of revelation, the truth as it has been
imparted to us by God, truth as it has been thrown down from
heaven to purify and enrich the earth with its abundant and soul-
saving blessings, raises us, and dignifies our nature. By truth
alone we can live, by truth alone is the moral fabric sustained.
The contending influences of our nature, which the Midrash typi-
fies by angels, are lulled and quieted, and man stands forth a
mighty, grand, and noble handiwork of the Creator. Yes, my
3

friends, God threw down truth from the heavens upon the earth.
He scattered it broadcast upon the earth. Oh then, my friends,
stoop and raise it up; let it not lie there discarded and neglect-
ed; let it not become soiled and tarnished; let not the sand and
dirt of a worldly indifference cover and conceal the precious heir-
loom of our God. If you would only Hebrew seek it
as hidden treasures,—nay, if you only bend your knee to it in-
stead of bending the knee to Baal, you will soon become enriched
and have gained the most costly treasure in the world. Only
stoop to pick it up. There it lies, open, free, accessible to all.
It is not in the heavens that thou shouldst say, Who will go up to
heaven and bring it to us? It is nigh at hand, surrounding the
whole world. The sands of the sea are not more abundant than
the truth of the word of God. The whole work of heaven and
earth bear evidence to that truth. It is to be found every where.
Graceful, beautiful, and brilliant, it shines forth from the sod on
which it has been cast by an Almighty hand. Like the crimson
violet, and other variegated blossoms which spring spontaneously
from the soil and shine resplendently in the sunlight sent from
heaven, the words of our Lord send up a hallowing influence, a
beautiful light, a bright, shining vividness, and an abundant life-
giving influence to all who seek the truth. Yes, the truth as it
came from God is universal, it is to be seen and felt every where,
not confined to one sphere, but abounding in every part of the
habitable globe. Like the gilded myriads of living creatures
that fly up from the earth and gambol and sport in the air, mak-
ing the atmosphere a scene of life and pleasure, so doth the truth,
as it was sent down to the earth, send up currents of life, filling
the air which we breathe with the blessings of joy and pleasure.
Oh then, my friends, in the name of that truth which is Israel's
pride, Israel's glory, and Israel's blessing, receive it and live by
it; live by it; and die in it; forsake it not, reject it not; but
receive it; there it lies, ready at hand; as you would stoop to pick
up a bright, shining blossom, stoop and pick up the word of
truth; as you would pluck a rose and adorn your breast with it,
which after all will not live long, so pluck the truth from the
earth and press it to your hearts, and adorn yourselves with it; for
when there it shall live and not wither. And this is the princi-

ple that should govern us in the Synagogue. Truth, the solemn
truth should govern us here. Here we come to give expression
to the truth, as it is felt within us. Here we come to make con-
fession of the truth which we may gather from the works of God.
But more especially here,—we come to imbibe the truth from
that living fount which you see before you (pointing to the ark).
We come here with no other principles but the principles of
truth. The hypocrite, the dissembler shall have no communion
with us. The utterer of deceits and lies shall not pollute this
sacred place. His foot shall not trample the truth of our God
under foot. No, before he walketh in here, he shall divest his feet
of the covering of sin and iniquity; he shall cleanse them in the
waters of purification, and in the naked simplicity of a regenerated
spirit, walk before the Lord, and stand upon the truth of an only
and indivisible God.

Let then truth be our watchword and our rallying cry. Let
it govern us in all our thoughts, sayings, and doings. Let it
never forsake us. Let it stimulate us in the cause of our holy
religion. Let it always be in our hearts, as well as uttered by the
word of our lips. Let it rise and grow like a full grown and vigor-
ous tree. Let it spring up like pure and graceful blossoms, giv-
ing life and health to our souls, so that because Hebrew
"truth springs up from the earth," Hebrew "the attribute
of God's righteousness, and His charity may beam down upon us
from His holy abode in heaven, and bless his people Israel and
the land which He swore to give unto our ancestors, a land flow-
ing with milk and honey!"

Let us now, my friends, look to the third question which we
have proposed to consider, viz: What should the Synagogue be
to us? This, my friends, is a very important consideration. Im-
portant for the moral points involved therein, as well as for the
historical considerations, as well as for the religious feature con-
nected with our destiny, as well for the past as for the future of
Judaism; for when we shall have considered this question well
in all its bearings, I am confident that you will see the Synagogue
not only in the light of a mere handsome building, not in the light
of a mere institution, subject like all other institutions, to the influ-
ence of change and improvement, but in the light of an eternal

principle, in the light of a living fact, a reality to be saved, pre-
served, watched, cared for, and handed down to posterity in all
the sublimity of its pristine integrity.

The Synagogue, my friends, should be to us a monumental re-
cord of the past; it should tend to connect the present with the
past. If there be one miracle palpably and evidently seen in
these days of scientific discoveries, when the folly and the wick-
edness of some men have led them to deny the agency of any
superhuman power in the rise and fall of nations, that miracle
is the existence of the Synagogue. For notwithstanding all the
efforts to destroy Judaism, which have been made from time to
time, and the interdicting of our worship, so as to merge us among
the other nations of the earth, the Synagogue still exists. Won-
derful testimony of Divine truth! There thou standest a mes-
senger of Heaven to proclaim the truth! There thou standest,
holding the olive branch of love and conciliation to all who shall
believe in the goodness and power of God! There thou standest,
in the native simplicity of thy own pure attribute of truth, de-
claiming that, though monuments, and thrones, and palaces, and
powers, and empires shall fall and crumble to the dust, thou wilt
stand as the appointed servant of God, until the day when all
men shall acknowledge the Unity of one Eternal Power. The
Synagogue is the monument which connects our present with our
past history
therefore should it be preserved from foreign influ-
ences which belong not to the history of Judaism; therefore should
we come here to learn our duties. Yea, here we may see Sinai
flaming in the fires of Heaven; here we may hear the thunders,
and listen to the trumpet notes which gathered our ancestors
round the holy scene; here by an historical evidence which the
Synagogue presents us of the facts of the history of revelation,
we may see with our mind's eye, and hearken with the Divine
faculty of our spirit to the amazing sound which filled our fathers'
hearts with love and veneration.

The Synagogue represents the principles taught by Moses in
the wilderness, when the children of Israel received the Law from
God. There they were told, "Not with you alone hath the Lord
made this covenant and this oath of denunciation, but with those
who stand here this day and those who stand not here this day."

Well have our sages paraphrased this by saying, all the forth-
coming souls of Israel were present on that occasion. Yes, my
brethren, the principles taught on that glorious day are as bind-
ing upon all the forthcoming generations of Israel, as if they had
been there;—and the institutions of our faith, the Synagogues
and temples erected by Israel, have always been monuments in
the life of Israel, connecting the existing time with that on which
Israel received the Law. In the Temple stood that very ark of
the covenant which Moses commanded our fathers to make as a
testimony to the truth of revelation. There stood, also, the table
of show bread and other historical memetoes, connecting the
existing time with the giving of the word of God in the wilder-
ness of Sinai; and even now, in our dispersion, we have memen-
toes of that glorious time. Here are read every Sabbath seven
portions of that Law which God gave our ancestors, so that the
whole is finished once every year, and renewed again; so that the
spirit of truth might thereby be sustained in Israel. Here we
are reminded, by historical associations, of Israel's new career. In
our prayers we recite those incidents of distress and happiness
which our fathers experienced, all leading us back, by successive
stages, to the period when Israel stood before Sinai; so that it
may, indeed, be figuratively said, our souls were present at the
giving of the Law on Sinai.

The Synagogue, then, should emphatically be looked upon as
a monumental record of the past.

Judaism, my friends, unlike any other system, derives its ex-
istence from two distinct ages—from the past and the future. It
lives in the present age, but not by the present age. It has no-
thing in common with the present age. Like the people of whom
Balaam prophesied, "Behold this people shall dwell alone and
not be counted among the nations," so is Judaism, surrounded on
all sides with systems of faith, with religious ideas, and views of
public worship, but partakes of none. Its attribute is individu-
ality, its characteristic is its adaptation for the people to whom
it was given as their everlasting inheritance. We do not deny
ourselves the pleasing hope and the full realization of the promise
of its becoming, eventually, the prevailing and universal faith;
but at the present time it is only a Jewish religion, made for the
3*

Israelite. It is to the Jew the religion derived from the past;
but it will be to the world at large the religion of the future.
The Israelite is encouraged to adhere to his faith by the convic-
tions of the past and the hopes of the future. Thus Sinai is the
fountain from which he gathers his life, and the Mount of Olives,
flourishing in all the vital grandeur which God has promised to
endow it with, is his incentive to continue faithful and zealous in
the service of his faith.

Judaism does not derive its life from the present. What is
there, my friends, in the present agitated state of the world, in
its theories and practices of religion, to commend itself to the
Israelite? Answer all those that feel enchanted by the spirit
of the age; answer all those who would wish the Synagogue to
undergo an entire remodeling from its ancient standard, and to
adapt itself to the fancies of the age; answer all those who would
wish the Synagogue not to draw its life-current from the rising
and swelling waves of a future sea of glory, which shall cover the
earth with its streams of knowledge and virtue, and would have
it chain itself down to the materiality of the present age!

No, no; the Synagogue must not be changed; it must stand as
the true exponent of the principles, the dogmas, the historical
recollections of the past, and the hopes, the solemn, the sacred
and sublime hopes and wishes, of the future of Israel. It must
stand as a monumental record, recording the exploits, the trials,
the vicissitudes, the calamities, and the sufferings which our peo-
ple suffered and patiently endured, in behalf of their glorious
faith, and also as a glorious bequest to our sons and daughters,
to lead them in the same path of hope and trust in the certain
promises of a God of truth, who has promised to send in the Re-
deemer to gather us together to the "land which He has given
unto us, as He has sworn unto our fathers, a land flowing with
milk and honey."

And is there any thing unreasonable in handing down the
Synagogue in this form? Let those who differ with us maintain
the opposite view, but as for us, let our reason and the assurances
given us by God, through His prophets, be our guide. Do not
think it strange that I should employ the term reason in this con-
nection. Reason aided by the word of God is a legitimate arbiter

in matters of this kind, and in fact, there is nothing in Scripture
which is opposed to true reason. Reason, then, is supported by
Scripture. Why should I not hope for the final triumph of our
faith in accordance with the prediction of HOLY WRIT? Our rea-
son, my friends, is influenced by history. We are taught, edu-
cated, and led by the history of the past. The history of Juda-
ism teaches the Israelite to believe that he is under the care of
a God. There is also a feeling in the heart of man which teaches
him to rely on the efficacy of repentance, and the reconciliation
which he can effect thereby with his Maker.

Why, then, dost thou, unbeliever, wish me to give up my hopes
of a glorious future? Why dost thou wish Israel to abandon the
hope of a restoration to the land of promise? God is good and
merciful. He brought our fathers to Palestine, in virtue of a
promise He made to their ancestors. He promised to keep them
there if they would obey His voice, to disperse them if they dis-
obeyed Him; but He is a God of mercy; and He also assured
them that He would again settle their children in their land, if
they would return to Him with a full heart.

Man requires an incentive to virtue and repentance. Cut off
the incentive, and you destroy the influence of repentance. Would
you have Israel think the prophets deceivers, and thereby harden
their hearts against repentance? I hope not! But whatever may
be the views of others, I trust that you, my brethren, will look
upon the Synagogue as a monument of the past, and a beacon-
light to the future. Yes; let it be a monument teaching all the
moral as well as religious duties. When you look upon the very
timbers of this house, let it remind you of the cedars of Lebanon,
the mighty oaks which are formed by the breath of God; let the
stones remind you of the Rock of ages; let the brass and other
metallic substances of this place, bring to your mind the omnipo-
tence of God, and that the most powerful of all earthly things
will vanish and melt by the breath of the Lord. In every respect,
this house should be a monument reminding us of the love, the
mercy, and the profound solicitude of God. According to some
of our teachers, the temple was constructed after the model of
the heavens, to remind us of the supreme wisdom of God. Let the
Synagogue no less remind us of the wisdom and the grace of that

Being who gave us a law and a creed by which we should live
and be happy;—yea, when we enter the Synagogue let it be to us
a monument reminding us of the abiding care and protection of
our heavenly Father, who has sustained us amidst all the trials to
which our people have been for ages exposed; and let us, above
all, look upon the Synagogue not as a mere structure designed
by the art and skill of man, but as a principle to be transmitted
to our children, so that they may be led to reflect that God's
abode is in heaven, and that He in His Providence will again
bless the land which He gave unto us, as He swore "unto our
fathers, a land flowing with milk and honey."

Lastly, what should we be to the Synagogue? We have con-
sidered, why we have erected a Synagogue; what principles should
govern us therein; what the Synagogue should be to us. And we
come now to the essential question, What should we be to the
Synagogue? This is at once met by the reply, We should be its
supporters. But in using this word, I do not mean that we are to
be its supporters in a financial point of view alone. We may
endow it ever so richly; we may offer and contribute ever so liber-
ally; we may build its walls of granite, its columns of marble,
its roof of the strongest timbers. We may use the strongest
cement, in causing its various parts to adhere. We may employ
workmen to excel the artisans of Tyre. We may lay the strong-
est materials in the known world, and the most costly jewels and
precious stones, under contribution: and yet the house will not
endure. If the Synagogue should be to us a monument of the
past, then we should no less be to the Synagogue the pillars by
which it may stand firm before the Lord. If we devote ourselves
to the service of the Synagogue, then will it endure; for the prin-
ciples, of which the building is but the reflex, will stand and endure
forever,—received, acknowledged, and revered by our children
and children's children; and though these walls shall have crum-
bled into dust, though not one single vestage of this place shall be
left, yet, the spiritual Synagogue, which is the real Synagogue,
will exist, supported by the columns of faith, charity, and love.
The sanctuary of eternal truth will be preserved from the ravages
of time, the influences of modern change, and the capricious and
whimsical agencies brought to bear upon every other institution

of the age; because supported by the pillars of an ardent faith,
it shall go down to posterity as their place of refuge in the hour
of danger and distress. The Temple of Solomon was strong; its
pillars mighty and stupendous; yet it fell. The altar of our
God on which were once sacrificed the oblations of a pious and
devoted people, who came to the sanctuary to serve their God,
became a pile of rubbish, and what was once the glory of God is
now a heap of ashes. And why was this? Was it from any
defect in the builder's skill? Did the workmen not honestly per-
form their allotted labor? No! no! whatever human skill could
do was done; whatever could be effected towards rearing a strong
and powerful monument of earthly grandeur, was ably, diligently,
and efficiently executed; but there was one thing omitted—the
columns which supported the building were not strong enough,—
they were not made of the right material—they were made of
stone, of the cold, lifeless granite—sad emblem of death,—they
were made of dead materials, and not out of the living pillars of
affection and duty. Oh! if Israel had supported the sanctuary
with its living heart; if, instead of turning a deaf ear to the
voice of God, it had listened, respected, and obeyed: its vital
heart would have been the best support to the Temple and its
holy altar. Oh! my friends, be ye then monuments to the Syna-
gogue, and rear your children in the faith of the true and living
God, so that by you, and after your day has been spent, by your
children, the Synagogue may be firmly established.

What the Synagogue needs is zealous hearts, devoted souls,
and pious minds; these are its best and most reliable pillars. Oh!
then, come to the house of God, and be its strength and support.
Desert it not, but maintain it with the truth of a devoted and
zealous attachment; sustain it with your hearts; uphold it by
professing here and elsewhere, the eternal principles of our holy
and glorious creed: then shall it stand a proud and lasting pinnacle
to the majesty, the glory, and the goodness of Israel's God,—yea,
then shall it stand as a pillar directing us to the abode of God
which is in heaven, from whence He will look down upon His
people Israel, and bless them and the land which He has given
unto them, as He swore unto their fathers, a land flowing with
milk and honey.

And now let us pray, that the Lord may be with us as He was
with our fathers, to direct our hearts to love and fear Him, and
preserve us from all evil. May he also strengthen our minds,
that we may know Him, serve Him, and love Him, and maintain
steadfast the Truth in all its integrity and purity. Amen.
